Question
========
  
In the summer of 2009, 944 military personnel were polled on whether they agreed that they should immediately withdraw from Iraq. According to politicians, "only a quarter of the military" would agree. In the sample, 274 military personnel agreed with this statement. The rest disagreed. Does this data show that the politicians' distribution of agree/disagree is correct? Test at $\alpha = .01$ . 
Answerlist
----------
* TRUE because 2.86 < 3.84 (= critical value)
* TRUE because 8.16 < 9.21 (= critical value)
* No, because 0.21 < 0.25 (= critical value)
* Yes, because 8.16 > 6.63 (= critical value)
